They do not have transportation to get to work which costs them a lot of money for traveling, so Rith is asking for his first loan of $700 to purchase a motorcycle.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike to get to work.

loans.name: Sokha

texts.en: Mrs. Sokha N. has been married for more than 30 years and has four daughters. Two of them are married; one sells silk goods in the village, and the other attends school. Sokha is a silk weaver. She has asked for Kiva loans twice, and is now asking for another loan of $100 pay school fees (English class) for her daughter.

loans.use: To pay school fees for her daughter.

loans.name: Hun

texts.en: Mrs. Hun V., 43, and her husband Mr. Heang Sin, 45, live along national road number one, about thirty-five kilometers from Phnom Penh. They have been married since 1991 and have six children — two sons and four daughters. Unfortunately, three of them died. Two are garment factory workers and another one attends school. Her husband is a fisherman. Hun sells fish that her husband catches and also buys some fish from other fisherman to sell in her village. She is asking for her first loan of $1,000 to purchasing fishing materials and a boat for her husband’s business.

loans.use: To purchasing fishing materials and boat for her husband’s business.

loans.name: Rin

texts.en:
Mrs. Rin M., a widow, has six children — five sons and one daughter: three of them are married and live outside the family home, one has full-time employment in Phnom Penh and the other two assist their mother in farming. The family lives on an Island in the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Mrs. Rin M. has been a weaver since 2005. She is also a farmer who grows ginger. She is requesting a loan of US$1,200 to purchase weaving materials for her weaving business and will use a part of her loan to buy seeds, fertilizer and pesticide to maintain her ginger farm.

loans.use: To purchase weaving materials for her weaving business and for farm use.

loans.name: Houng

texts.en:
Mr. Houng L. and his wife, Mrs. Phon Prum have been married since 1983 and have nine children — seven sons and two daughters. The family lives on an Island in the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Houng and his wife are farmers. He is also a fisherman. When the harvest season comes, the couple sells their produce to a middleman in the village so they do not need to travel to Phnom Penh to sell any more. 

Houng is a asking for a loan of $200 to purchase seed, fertilizer and pesticides to maintain his farm.

loans.use: To use for farming.

loans.name: Sochea

texts.en:
Mrs. Sochea L. (pictured with her son) is 31 years old and her husband, Mr. Kry Yin, is 38 years old. They live along National Road Number Six about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia. They have been married since 1995 and have three children: two sons and one daughter. Mr. Kry Yin is a fisherman. 

Sochea sells fish that her husband catches in her village. She is asking for a loan of $1,000 to purchase fishing materials for her husband’s business and to buy a motorcycle for commuting.

loans.use: To purchase fishing materials and a motorcycle

loans.name: Lolita

texts.en:
Lolita J. is 46 years old, married and supports her family by operating two business ventures: Internet & Computer games and buying and selling mineral water. She lives in Basak Merkado, Brgy. Basak, Lapu-Lapu City, Cebu. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2009 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her Internet & Computer games and buying and selling mineral water businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 20,000. Lolita is now borrowing PHP 15,000 to purchase new equipment. This will be her fourth loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 10,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Lolita aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future wellbeing by following the Dungganon way. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by joining the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org.

loans.use: For additional working capital

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Vanh

texts.en:
Vanh C. A. is 28 years old and a married womA. with one lovely young child. She lives in Kompong Chhnang Province. Vanh C. A. currently owns a small fish selling business. She buys dried and smoked fish in bulk from her neighbors and then sells retail fish in her community. Her husband is a staff member in a private company. 

Vanh C. A. is a hard-working womA. who never wastes time while engaging in her business. As a result of the increasing demands of her customers, Vanh C. A. is applying for a loA. so she cA. purchase more dried and smoked fish to sell.

loans.use: to purchase fish

loans.name: Tem

texts.en:
Mrs. Tem T. (pictured here) and her husband, Mr. Korn Som, have been married since 1979. They have three sons and three daughters. 

Tem is hired by people in her village to put together fabric swatches to sell to a clothing manufacturer and she also assists her husband in his rice farming business. In the past, she used to sell cupcakes. 

Tem is applying for a loan of 800 USD to purchase seed fertilizer and pesticide for the rice farm. She will also use a part of the loan to buy a motorcycle for commuting.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer and pesticide

loans.name: Thourk

texts.en:
Mr. Thourk O. (pictured here) is 36 years old, and his wife, Mrs. Leakhena Yean, is 28 years old. They live along National Road Number Six about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia. They have been married since 1994 and have three sons and one daughter. Three of their children are in school and the fourth is too young. 

Mr. Thourk O. has been a construction contractor for 12 years. His wife stays at home to take care of the children and the main source of family income is from Thourk’s business.  Thourk is asking for a loan of 1,200 USD to purchase materials for his construction business.

loans.use: to purchase construction materials

loans.name: Norie

texts.en:
Norie C. is a married woman who lives in Lapu-Lapu st., Poblacion, Madredijos, Cebu City. She earns her living by operating three business ventures: general store, buying and selling chicken, and dried fish.  Her husband, Lopito C., who is 60 years old, works as a driver/mechanic to earn his living and helps in his wife's business activities.  They have eight children who are between 19 and 36 years old. Norie joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2002 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 17 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Norie has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 21,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 9000, improving the family's standard of living.  This time, for her 18th loan, she is borrowing PHP 22,000, which she intends to use as additional working capital to save up for the future for her business operations. Norie C. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the   NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: For additional working capital

loans.name: Thea

texts.en:
Mr. Thea B. (pictured with his daughter) is 42 years old and his wife, Mrs. Mouly Kong, is 39 years old. They live in a suburb of Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia. They have three children: one son and two daughters. Two of them are garment factory workers and the other is still young.

Thea is a construction worker. His wife is a chef. He is asking for his first loan of $700. He will use $500 to purchase a motorcycle for his children to get work and another $200 to build a restroom for the family’s use.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle and build a restroom

loans.name: Koeun

texts.en:
Mr. Koeun D. (shown in the photo) is 42 years old and his wife, Mrs. Thoeun Oeun is 47 years old. They live on an Island in Mekong River about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia. They have been married for almost 20 years and have five children: three sons and two daughters. One was hired to sell food, one is a wooden house constructor and three are in school.  

Koeun is a motorbike repairman. His wife stays at home and does housework. He is asking for his first loan in the amount of $300 to repair the house where he lives.

loans.use: To repair his house

loans.name: Bayaraa

texts.en:
Bayaraa P. is a married, 35-year-old women who lives with her husband their two-year-old son in the Hovd province of Mongolia. He and her family live together in a ger, which is a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Her son is in kindergarten, while her husband works in the dental hospital. 

To earn a living and to support her family, Bayaraa operates a taxi service in her town by using her own car. She began her taxi business in 2008 and has gained a great deal of experience as a driver since then. Bayaraa is a modest and outgoing women who says that "If my car is in good condition, then I can continue to operate my taxi service for a living." She is now requesting a loan in the amount of 500,000 MNT ($425) in order to make repairs to her car.

loans.use: To improve his business by making repairs

loans.name: Chan

texts.en:
Mrs. Chan T. (pictured) is 47 years old. She and her husband, Mr. Phat Kroch, who is 48 years old, have been married since 1987. They have two children: one son and one daughter. Their son is in school, while their daughter is married and lives outside the family home.

To support their family, Chan and her husband are silk weavers. They sell their finished products to a middleman, who takes their products to Phnom Penh or other places to re-sell for profits. In addition, the couple also farms to generate income.

Chan is now seeking a loan in the amount of $600 to both purchase weaving materials to better operate her weaving business and to buy a water-pumping machine to spray her farm.

loans.use: To expand and improve her businesss by purchasing weaving materials and a water-pumping machine

loans.name: Savoeun

texts.en:
Mrs. Savoeun C. (pictured in the photo) is a married, 52-year-old woman. Her husband, Mr. Song Sorn, is 52 years old, and they have been married since 1979. They have ten children: two sons and eight daughters. She notes that several of their children are married and live outside of their family home. She and her husband live on an island on the Mekong River, approximately 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia.

To earn a living and to support her family, Savoeun sells desserts in her village. She buys ingredients from the local market and makes desserts from scratch by herself. Her husband is a weaver by profession. She is requesting her first loan in the amount of $200 to make additional desserts, which she will then sell for profits.

loans.use: To expand her business by making and selling additional desserts

loans.name: Kimsol

texts.en:
Mr. Kimsol S. (pictured in the photo) and his wife, Mrs. Tha Ron, live along National Road 5, approximately 17 kilometers from Phnom Penh. They have been married since 2001 and they have one daughter.

Kimsol is a mason by profession, while his wife is a garment factory worker. He is seeking a loan in the amount of $400 to connect his house to a private water and electricity utility service and to build up the land on which their house is situated.

loans.use: To improve their house by connecting to better water/electricity services

loans.name: Edina

texts.en:
Edina Q. is a 64-year-old woman from Capatan, Tuguegarao City. Edina is a widow with seven adult-age children. To make a living, Edina owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector by raising livestock. She explains that her primary source of income is derived from raising pigs and re-selling them for profits. Edina has been engaged in this business for over six years and earns approximately 4,500 PHP per month from these activities.

In 2005, Edina joined ASKI to gain much-needed access to financial services. As a result, she was better able to engage in business activities and to improve her family's standard of living. Recently, Edina successfully repaid a prior loan in the amount of 10,000 PHP from ASKI. Edina is now requesting a new loan, this time in the amount of 5,000 PHP ($125), which would be used to purchase young livestock to raise and sell in the future. Notably, this loan would be her fifth loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business as a result of the loan to improve and expand her business.

About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas of the country. Its clients mostly consist of farmers, fishermen/women, and entrepreneurs.

loans.use: To expand and improve her business by purchasing and ultimately selling additional livestock

loans.name: Sao

texts.en:
Sao S. is a married, 26-year-old woman. To earn a living, she works as a garment worker at the garment industry in the province of Kompong Chhnang. She has been working in this profession since 2008 and typically earns an income of approximately $2.50 per day.

Sao Sok's husband is basket maker. She explains that he is very good at making bamboo baskets, which he then sells at the market. On average, he earns at least $2 per day to cover their family’s daily living expenses. They married each other a few years ago, but they do not yet have any children. Sao S.’s husband would like to invest in his business to generate additional profits. As a result, Sao S. is requesting a loan from Kiva in the amount of $250 so that her husband can purchase materials to make his baskets.

loans.use: To expand and improve the business by purchasing materials for baskets

loans.name: Chantha

texts.en:
Mrs. Chantha K. (pictured here) and her husband, Mr. Ngoun, have been married since 1979 and have six children: three sons and three daughters. One is married and lives in a separate home, two attend school whilst the others are garment-factory workers. The family lives along National Road Number 5 about 17 kilometers from Phnom Penh City.

Chantha is a rice farmer. She just started a tailoring business for when she is not at the farm. Her husband is a fisherman and also assists his wife on the farm. Chantha asked for a Kiva loan one time already; she now is asking for another loan of $700 to purchase a water-pumping machine to spray her rice farm and to buy seeds, fertilizer and pesticide.

loans.use: To purchase a water-pumping machine to spray her farm

loans.name: Loeng

texts.en:
Mrs. Loeng T. (pictured here) sells ansorm (a kind of Cambodian cake made of rice paste and wrapped in banana leaves) in her village. She has been married since 2006. Her husband, Mr. Phalla Chan, is a construction worker. They live in a small village along National Road Number 5 about 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh and have six children: three sons and three daughters.

In addition, the couple also grows rice. Loeng asked for a Kiva loan one time already; she now is asking for her second loan of $1,200 to purchase a motorcycle for commuting and she will also use a part of her loan to continue her farming business.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle for commuting and to use for growing rice

loans.name: Seng

texts.en:
Mr. Seng C. (in the photo) is 46 years old and his wife, Mrs. Seda Ka, is 40 years old. They live along National Road 5, about 25 kilometers from Phnom Penh. They have been married since 1992 and have two daughters. 

Seng is a construction worker. His wife sells food, rice and coffee in the village. He is in the process of building a new house to stay in, but it is not finished yet. Hence, Seng is asking for his first loan of $1,000 to finish building his house.

loans.use: To finish building his house

loans.name: Juliet

texts.en:
Juliet L. is from Capatan, Tuguegarao City. She is 50 years old. Juliet is married and has two infant-aged children. To make a living, Juliet owns and operates a business venture making and selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling ice cream to the local community. Juliet has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Juliet joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Juliet has successfully repaid a previous loan from ASKI. Juliet is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory and working capital to improve her business. This will be the third loan taken out by Juliet from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue she generates to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and working capital

loans.name: Rom

texts.en:
Mrs. Rom P. is 57 years old and her husband, Mr. Ben But, is 58 years old. They have been married since 1973 and have six sons. Three are married and live outside the family home, one is a construction worker, one is a fisherman and another is a farmer. The family lives in a small village along National Road number five, approximately 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh City. 

Rom is a tailor, and her husband is a rice farmer. She is asking for her first loan of $1,000 to purchase a motorcycle for her son to get to work. She will use part of the loan as capital for her husband’s farming business.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle for her son, and to use as capital for her husband's farming business

loans.name: Hai

texts.en:
Mr. Hai H. (pictured with his wife) is 57 year old, and his wife, Mrs. Samet Phon, is 58 years old. They have been married since 1980 and have three sons and one daughter. Two of their children are married and live outside the family home, one assists his father in his fishing business and another one attends school. The family lives about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh. 

Hai and his wife are fishermen. He is asking for his first loan of $1,200 to provide capital to his daughter, who is married, to purchase groceries for resale. He will also use a part of the loan to buy fishing materials for his business.

loans.use: To provide capital to his daughter to purchase groceries for resale and to buy fishing material for his fishing business

loans.name: Kea

texts.en:
Mrs. Kea H. (pictured with her husband) is 28 year old and her husband, Mr. Mada Moeun, is 27 years old. They have been married since 2007 and just had a young son. The family lives about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh City. 

Mrs. Kea H. and her husband are farmers. They grow cauliflower on their farmland in the village where they live. Kea is requesting her first loan of $600 to purchase seeds, fertilizer and pesticides to maintain her cauliflower farm.

loans.use: To use for farming

loans.name: Chantha

texts.en:
Mrs. Chantha T. and her husband, Mr. Phally Pheng, have been married since 1986 and have two sons and two daughters. One of them is married and lives outside the family home, one works in a garment factory, one is a fisherman and another one attends school. The family lives along national road number one, approximately 35 kilometers from Phnom Penh City. 

Chantha is a rice farmer. She has asked for a Kiva loan once before. She is now applying for her second loan of $300 to purchase a boat and a boat motor for her son’s fishing business.

Photo: Mrs. Chantha T. and her husband

loans.use: To purchase a boat and a boat motor for her son’s fishing business

loans.name: Soth

texts.en: The man shown in the picture above, Mr. Soth S., is a 30-year-old married man who works as a vet in Kompong Chhnang Province. He has a life partner in his wife who is a local famer. Mr. Soth S. also assists his wife when he has free time from his work. Mr. Soth S.’s wife has been planting the rice crop on her farmland. She is able to plant the crops at least twice a year by following both rainy and dry seasons. In the past, Mr. Soth S.’s wife has always hired the neighbor’s cow to assist with the chore of plowing the farmland. Right now, she hopes to buy her own cow, but her account does not have enough money in it. That is why Mr. Soth S. is looking for a loan as capital to support his wife’s farming business. He will use the loan to buy a cow to plow the farmland and to pick up rice during harvest seaS..

loans.use: To buy a cow

loans.name: Melanie

texts.en:
Melanie B. is a single parent who lives in Buot, Brgy. Pta Engaño, Cordova, Cebu. She earns her living by operating a sari-sari (general) store and selling food. Melanie joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2009 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past two loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Melanie has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 6,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 22,400, uplifting the family's standard of living. This time, for her third loan, she is borrowing PHP 9,000, which she intends to use to purchase more inventory to sell. Her goal is to continue to save for the future expansion of her business, for her children’s education, and for the purchase of a house and lot. Melanie B. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: 
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: To purchase inventory

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine S. is 46 years old, married, and supports her family by selling food and vegetables. She lives in Prk. Calasa, Brgy. Caradio-an, Himamaylan City, Negros Occidental. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2007 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 3,000. Josephine is now borrowing PHP 9,500 so that she can continue to fund the operation of her business selling food. This will be her sixth loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 9,500, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Josephine aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way. 

About NWTF: 
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: To fund the operation of her business selling food

loans.name: Merlita

texts.en:
Merlita M. is from the village of Esperanza West. She is forty years old. Merlita is married with two school-aged children. Merlita owns and operates a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Merlita has been engaged in her business for over ten years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Merlita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services. Merlita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Merlita is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP for the same purpose. This loan will be her fourth loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay her children's tuition fees. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand product offering

loans.name: Caridad

texts.en:
Caridad D. is from the village of Salucong. She is 44 years old. Caridad is married with five school-aged children. She owns and operates a business venture raising crops. The main source of income for the business comes from growing and selling a variety of vegetables. Caridad has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Caridad joined ASKI to gain access to financial services. Caridad has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. Caridad is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young plants to raise. This loan will be her fourth loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay her children's tuition fees. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young plants.

The main source of income for the business comes from raising cattL. for saL.. Ngoan has been engaged in this business for over nine years and earns approximately 2,000,000 VND a month.

In 2010, Ngoan joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to gain access to financial services. She is requesting a loan of 3,079,800 VND which will be used to invest in expanding the business. The loan will be her first loan from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.

loans.name: Marcelina

texts.en:
Marcelina B. is a married woman who lives in Brgy. Camburong, Oslob, Cebu. She earns her living by operating two business ventures: a pig fattening and motorcycle business. Her husband, Onesimo B., who is 54 years old, works as a driver to earn his living. They have six children who are between 11 and 30 years old. One of them has a family, while three others are working to help out in the house, and the youngest two go to school. Marcelina joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2005 because she aspired for something better for her family. Marcelina B. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path towards the achievement of her dreams. 

With the help of her past eight loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Marcelina has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 15,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 8,000, thus improving the family's standard of living. 

This time, for her ninth loan, she wants to borrow PHP 15,000 to use as additional capital for the business so that she can continue to save up for the future and support the family's needs. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.  Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Additional working capital

While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is 02.02.06-Hong Ky-Hoang Hoa.

Nien is married with two school-aged children. To making a living, Nien operates a family member's business venture in the services sector, renting out  furniture to local community members. Nien has been engaged in this business for over twenty years and earns approximately 2,000,000 VND a month.

In 2010, Nien joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to gain access to financial services. She is requesting a loan of 3,079,800 VND which will be used to expand the business. The loan will be her first loan from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Josefina

texts.en:
Josefina L. is a 36-year-old married woman who supports her family by operating two businesses: vegetable farming and food vending. She lives in Brgy. Cagubaan, Alegria, Cebu. 

Josefina has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2007 and has improved her living conditions with both the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard on her vegetable farm and food vending businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 4,000.  

Josefina wants to borrow PHP 13,000 so that she can purchase new equipment. This will be her seventh loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 14,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step on her journey towards economic freedom. Josefina hopes to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well being by following the Dungganon way.  

About NWTF:  In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Purchase of farm equipment

Hieu is married with three adult-aged children. To making a living, Hieu operates a family member's business venture selling home products. The main source of income for the business comes from selling personal home products to tourists and local community members. Hieu has been engaged in this business for over 25 years and earns approximately 2,000,000 VND a month.

In 2010, Hieu joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to gain access to financial services. She is requesting a loan of 3,079,800 VND which will be used to expand the business. loans.name: Leona

texts.en:
Leona L. is a married woman who lives in Brgy. Valencia, Alegria, Cebu. She earns her living by operating a farm. Her husband Romulo L., who is 53 years old, works as a farmer to earn his living. They have three children who are between 20 and 25 years old--two of them are already working while one is currently going to school. 

Leona joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2007 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past six loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Leona has been lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 11,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 10,000, thus uplifting the family's standard of living.  

This time, for her seventh loan, she wants to borrow PHP 12,000 which she intends to use to expand her business so that she can continue to save up for the future and their family's needs. Leona L. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path towards the achievement of her dreams.  

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.  Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

Romula L. is a widow who lives in Brgy. Valencia, Alegria, Cebu. She earns her living by operating two businesses: a general store and video rental. She has three children who are between 30 and 38 years old.

This time, for her seventh loan, she hopes to borrow PHP 15,000 to purchase more stock to sell. Romula L. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path towards the achievement of her dreams.

Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ bán các sản phẩm gia dụng cá nhân cho du khách và người dân trong cộng đồng địa phương.  Toi thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 10 năm.  Từ các hoạt động này, Toi kiếm được khoảng 2,000,000 VND.  Vào 2010, Toi đã tham gia Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải T.ện  sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy.  Toi đề nghị khoản vay lần đầu tiên từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.    Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 3,079,800 VND.


Khoản vay sẽ là 1st khoản vay của người vay từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.


Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm:


1.  P. T. Hoan (58) là 51 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 3,079,800 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là sản xuất & buôn bán thức ăn.


2.  N. T. Lan (59) là 52 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 3,079,800 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là sản xuất & buôn bán thức ăn.


3.  C. T. Nguyet (60) là 25 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 3,079,800 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là sản xuất & buôn bán thức ăn.


4.  N. T. Tam (61) là 21 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 3,079,800 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là sản xuất & buôn bán thức ăn.


5.  D. T. Ha (062) là 49 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 3,079,800 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là sản xuất & buôn bán thức ăn.


Về Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

Nhiệm vụ của Quỹ Hỗ trợ Phụ Nữ Nghèo Thanh Hóa (FPW) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính bền vững cho những người phụ nữ kém may mắn ở các vùng nông thôn tỉnh Thanh Hóa.


*Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. .  Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng  Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.  ."

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Gaudencio

texts.en:
Gaudencio O. is a 59-year-old married man who supports his family through his business of buying and selling livestock.  He lives in Badian, Cebu.  He has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2005 and has improved his living conditions with the help of his loans from NWTF and through his own efforts. 

By working hard in his livestock  business, Gaudencio is gradually making his family more economically stable. He now earns an average monthly income of PHP7,000. Gaudencio is borrowing PHP 12,000 to  fund his business operations. This will be his ninth loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. His previous loan of PHP10,000, which he paid off well within its term, was just another step in his journey towards economic freedom. Gaudencio aspires to elevate his family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way.  

About NWTF:  In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through this program, NWTF is empowering people to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.  Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join.

loans.use: Additional working capital

loans.name: Evangeline

texts.en:
Evangeline  A. is a married woman who lives in Barangay Bugas, Badian, Cebu. She earns her living by operating 3 business ventures: a general store, a haircut business and a manicure business. Her husband Deocito A. helps her with her businesses.  The couple has 2 children who are 9 and 11 years old and are currently going to school. 

Evangeline joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2008 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 4 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Evangeline  has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 7,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 4,500, thus uplifting the family's standard of living.  This time, for her 5th cycle loan, she is borrowing PHP 10,000 which she intends to use to purchase more stock to sell.  With increased profits, she will be able to continue to save for the future and her children's education.  Evangeline  A. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path towards the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF:  In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through this program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.  Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join.
"

loans.use: To purchase more stock to sell

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Altanzul

texts.en:
Altanzul B. lives with her husband and youngest daughter in the Selenge province of Mongolia. She and her family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Her oldest daughter currently studies at a university in Japan through a scholarship program, and her youngest daughter attends a local primary school, while her middle son lives with his grandparents and will start attending university in 2011. Her husband is a construction worker, but is currently unemployed. 

Altanzul operates a consumer goods trading business out of a rented stall at the local market in her town. In 2007, she moved to her current town and started her business after operating a repair shop in a rented space in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia, between 2000 and 2007. Over the years, she has gained significant business experience and has built a positive reputation amongst her customers and suppliers. Her product procurement usually depends on the season, therefore she provides a variety of products that can satisfy her customers. After years of successful operation, she was able to build a house in her yard. For the future, Altanzul hopes to continue being successful with her business and enlarge her house. She has used her business earnings to pay for her daughter's school costs, which has caused her working capital to decrease. She is requesting a 2,500,000 MNT loan in order to increase her goods and also working capital for her business.

loans.use: To increase her goods and working capital

loans.name: Amantai

texts.en: Amantai A. is 42 years old and lives with her five children in Bayan-Ulgii province in western Mongolia. She and her children live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Her four children all attend a local secondary school. Amantai operates a meat selling business in her province. Herders travel up to 200 kilometers from their location to sell livestock to the meat wholesale trader in the town. In Bayan-Ulgii province, it is common for a household to buy at least one cow and 10 sheep to be eaten during the long Mongolian winters. People of this province usually prepare their meats for winter during October and November and finish those prepared meats in March. Amantai usually purchases livestock from herders and slaughters them to sell their meat at the local market. She sells a kilogram of lamb for 4,000 to 4,500 MNT and horse meat for 4,000 to 4,500 MNT, respectively. She hopes to continue her success and says, "all I want is to support my children." Amantai is requesting a 3,000,000 MNT loan to purchase more livestock at wholesale prices.

loans.use: To purchase more livestock at wholesale prices

loans.name: Kalira Echkilbaeva's Group

texts.en:
Kalira E. is the leader of this group. She is 50 and married. Kalira is the resident of a small town, Karabalta, which is located near Bishkek, the capital of Kyrgyzstan. She has a daughter and a son. Her son works in Russia, and her daughter makes money by working as a seller in the supermarket.  Kalira’s husband is retired. In order to earn money to cover their family's expenses, Kalira takes order and sews Kyrgyz national blankets, cloth and dressmaking supplies. She started her activity seven years ago with an initial investment of 5,000 soms. In this way, she earns 5,000 soms per month. This profit made it possible for her to save money and repair the house. With money received from the loan she wants to purchase fabrics and materials needed for sewing. In the future, Kalira wants to expand her business and open a sewing workshop.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase fabrics and materials

loans.name: Pangkung Liplip Indah Group

texts.en:
Ni Kadek S. is a 28 year-old female living in the town of Melaya, Bali.  Ni Kadek is the group leader of a 15-member group loan offered by MUK.  While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.  The official name of this borrowing group is Pangkung Liplip Indah (PK-10387).


Ni Kadek is married and has two school-aged children.  To making a living, Ni Kadek owns & operates a business raising pigs for sale.  Ni Kadek has been engaged in this business for over two years and earns approximately 200,000 IDR a month from these activities. The most fun part of this effort is to see pigs eat their food with gusto, so that they can grow big. Later, they can be sold at high prices.


In 2010, Ni Kadek joined MUK to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  Ni Kadek has successfully repaid a previous loan of 1,500,000 IDR from MUK.  This previous loan was used to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in the future.  She is now requesting a new loan of 1,500,000 IDR, which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in the future.  The loan will be the second loan taken out by the borrower from MUK.  Ni Kadek plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees for her children.

She is pursuing this business because she wants to help the family finance their children's schooling. She wanted her children to be educated up to college.



About MUK:

The mission of Koperasi Mitra Usaha Kecil (MUK) is to assist small businesses in Bali by providing training, business consultation and loans thereby helping the owners and their families improve their everyday lives.





Ni Kadek S. (0) merupakan 28 tahun wanita.  Dia (perempuan) tinggal di kota Melaya - Bali.  Ni Kadek adalah pemimpin kelompok sebuah kelompok peminjam yang terdiri atas 15 anggota.  Meskipun setiap anggota kelompok menerima pinjaman perorangan, mereka semua bertanggung jawab untuk mengembalikan pinjaman rekan anggota kelompok mereka jika ada yang menunggak atau gagal membayar.  Nama resmi kelompok peminjam ini adalah Pangkung Liplip Indah (PK-10387).


Meskipun bukan satu-satunya sarana untuk menghasilkan pendapatan, sumber utama penghasilan bisnis tersebut terutama berasal dari beternak babi untuk dijual.  Ni Kadek sudah menjalankan bisnis ini selama lebih dari 2 tahun.  Dari kegiatan-kegiatan ini, Ni Kadek menghasilkan sekitar 0,200 IDR.  Dalam 2010, Ni Kadek bergabung MUK untuk mendapatkan akses ke layanan keuangan untuk membantu meningkatkan  -nya kondisi kehidupan dan kemampuan untuk menjalankan kegiatan bisnis.  Ni Kadek telah berhasil melunasi pinjaman sebelumnya sebesar 1.500.000 IDR dari MUK.  Pinjaman sebelumnya ini digunakan untuk membE. bibit ternak untuk dibesarkan & dijual di masa mendatang.  Dia (perempuan) sekarang meminta pinjaman baru sebesar 1.500.000 IDR.


Pinjaman ini akan menjadi 2nd pinjaman yang diambil oleh peminjam dari MUK.


Tentang MUK:

Misi Koperasi Mitra Usaha Kecil (MUK) adalah untuk membantu usaha kecil di Bali dengan memberikan perlatihan, konsultasi bisnis, dan pinjaman uang, dengan demikian membantu pemilik usaha dan keluarga mereka memperbaiki hidup sehari-hari.


  "

loans.use: To purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in future

loans.name: Bauirjan

texts.en: Bauirjan H. is 26 years old and lives with his wife and two daughters in the Bayan-Ulgii province of Mongolia. He and his family live together in their own house and fence. Bauirjan owns a transportation service where he transports people using his own jeep between local sub-provinces. He started his transportation business in 2004 and has been successful enough to buy a car, which enabled him to start his second business driving a taxi to supplement his earnings. He has built a successful and stable operation and his earnings have enabled him to build a house and live on his own with his family. He makes 2-3 trips in one week between local towns and operates a taxi service during his free time within his town. His daily business income is between 15,000 and 25,000 MNT and his monthly average income has reached a level of 350,000 MNT. Bauirjan is a very honest and hardworking man and says, " I want to start saving my business profits in order to invest money for my children's future. " He is requesting a 1,500,000 MNT loan in order to purchase necessary spare parts for both of vehicles.

loans.use: To purchase necessary spare parts

loans.name: Dalaijargal

texts.en: Dalaijargal N. is 36 years old and lives with her husband and three sons in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic home, in Ulaanbaatar, a capital city of Mongolia. All three children attend school and her husband operates a transportation business using his own mini-truck to supplement his family income. Dalaijargal operates a grocery shop in the city. She started her grocery trading business in 2007 with a small shop. Since then, she has established her business into a sustainable level and she was able to obtain permission from Expertise Agency to operate a grocery shop. After several years of operation, she has gained much experience and today, her working capital exceeds 1,100,000 MNT. Her daily average sales income is between 50,000 and 100,000 MNT. In the future, she hopes to grow her business. She is requesting a 2,000,000 MNT loan in order to increase her working capital for her grocery shop.

loans.use: To grow her business

loans.name: Marites

texts.en:
Marites A. is from the village of Salay, Misamis Oriental. She is 42 years old. Marites is married and has two adult-aged children. To make a living, Marites owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop buying and selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, toothpaste, canned goods & junk food in the local community. Marites has been engaged in her business for over eight years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Marites joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marites has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to buy and sell. Marites is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products like beverages & breads. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Marites from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products like beverages & breads

loans.name: Alice

texts.en: Alice is married and a mother to four children who are in school. She operates a food stall in a busy part of Nairobi and her main customers are taxi drivers and conductors. She is 38 years old and has two employees. She is requesting a loan of 30,000 Kes to purchase ingredients for cooking. She describes herself as hardworking and patient and hopes to own a big hotel in the future. In five years, Alice plans to have built her own business premises.

In 2010, Lourdes joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lourdes has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory and increase working capital. Lourdes is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP that will be used to purchase additional products such as beverages and vegetables. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Lourdes from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products like beverages and vegetables

loans.name: Maribel

texts.en:
Maribel M. is from the village of Plaridel, Claveria, Misamis Oriental. She is 43 years old. Maribel is married and has 4 adult-aged children. To make a living, Maribel owns and operates a furniture making business. The main source of income for the business comes from making and selling general household furniture made from bamboo to local businesses and community members. Maribel has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Maribel joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Maribel has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory and increase working capital. Maribel is requesting a new loan of 4,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional raw materials to expand product offerings. This loan will be the 4th loan taken out by Maribel from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional raw materials to expand product offerings

loans.name: Virginia

texts.en:
Virginia is from the village of Pines, Oroquieta City. She is 33 years old, married and has two children. To make a living, Virginia runs a business as a farmer. Virginia has been engaged in her business for 3 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities. 

Virginia joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell.

Virginia is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP with which she will purchase additional inventory and use for working capital. This loan will be the fifth loan taken out by Virginia from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About PMPC
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. 

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Additional capital for her business

loans.name: Anesia

texts.en:
Anesia M. is a married woman who lives in Brgy. Oguis, Danao, Cebu. She earns her living by operating two businesses: a pig fattening operation and a farm. Her husband, Jose M., who is 51, works as a farmer and also helps in his wife's businesses. They have three children, who are between 17 and 31 years old. Anesia joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2009 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past three loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Anesia has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 9000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 12000, raising the family's standard of living. This time, for her fourth loan, she is borrowing PHP 12000, which she intends to use to purchase additional pigs and feed so that she can continue to saving for the future. Anesia M. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means "honorable"). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day, to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking on the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: To purchase extra pigs and feed

loans.name: Socrates

texts.en:
Socrates M. is a separated woman who lives in Proper, Brgy. Dungga, Danao City, Cebu. She earns her living by operating two businesses: a general store and a food vending businesses. She has two children, who are 13 and 19 years old. Socrates joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2008 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past three loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Socrates has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 10000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 3080, raising the family's standard of living. This time, for her fourth loan, she is borrowing PHP 12000, which she intends to use to purchase more stock so that she can continue saving for future house renovations and family needs. Socrates M. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means "honorable"). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking on the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: To purchase more stock to sell

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace L. is from the village of Talisayan, Misamis Oriental. She is 63 years old. Grace is widowed. To make a living, Grace owns and operates a business making & selling food. The main source of income for the business comes from making wedding foods, such as cakes and pastries, for the local community. Grace has been operated her business for more than 10 years and earns approximately 10000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2006, Grace joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her standard of living and her business. Grace has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. Grace is requesting a new loan of 9000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional raw ingredients needed to make cakes and pastries. This loan will be the fifth taken out by Grace from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.use: To purchase additional raw ingredients needed to make cakes and pastries

loans.name: Heidi Joy

texts.en:
Heidi Joy A. is from the village of Barangay 25, Gingoog City. She is 28 years old. Heidi Joy is married and has one school-aged child. To make a living, Heidi Joy owns and operates a business making and selling food. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from making and selling home made sausage, or chorizo, as well as pork and chicken barbecue for the local community. Heidi Joy has operated her business for more than a year and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Heidi Joy joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her business. Heidi Joy has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase raw ingredients. Heidi Joy is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional raw ingredients to make chorizo. This loan will be the second loan Heidi Joy has recieved from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials to make chorizo

location.town: Barangay 25, Pandan, Gingoog City, Mis. Or.

loans.name: Ouch

texts.en: Mr Ouch C., 48, is a villager living in Kampong Kor village, Kandal province. He and his wife, Mrs Lok Phorn (pictured), are farmers who own a plot of land to cultivate herbs (basil, romantic plant and parsley) for a living. They lack sufficient farming supplies, so Mr Ouch C. would like to ask for a loan to purchase gasoline, roses, fertilizers and pesticides. This couple has two children: one is a seamstress in a garment factory and the other is a farmer.

loans.use: To purchase gasoline, roses, fertilizers and pesticides

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace T. is from the village of Medina, Misamis Oriental. She is 35 years old. Grace is married and has two infant-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a business of buying and selling coconut for copra (dried coconut for making coconut oil) in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over nine years and earns approximately $250 a month for these activities.

In 2010, Grace joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional coconuts. This will be her 1st loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional coconuts

loans.name: Meas' Group

texts.en:
Twelve people make up this village bank loan. They are living in Srae Kouk village in Kandal province. This village bank loan selected Mrs. Meas M., who is 48 years old, as the village bank president. Each member will use their portion of the loan to support their different purposes. 

Mrs. Meas M. is a farmer who owns a one-hectare rice field to cultivate rice for a living. Now her rice field is ready to harvest, but she doesn’t have enough money to support it, so she decided to ask for a loan to hire farm laborers to harvest her rice field. Her husband, Mr. Chab Chhieng, 47 years old, works as a car driver and also helps in his wife's farming. 

This couple has five children, two of whom are car mechanics and three are students. who also support their parents' farming.

loans.use: To hire farm laborers to harvest her rice field.

loans.name: Riza

texts.en:
Riza B. is from the village of Binakalan, Gingoog City. She is 29 years old. Riza is a widow and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Riza owns and operates sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, toothpaste, canned goods and junk foods in the local community. She also buys and sells electronic loads from several networks like SMART & GLOBE. Riza has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately $125 a month for these activities.

In 2009, Riza joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. 

Riza is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products like breads and biscuits. This will be her 2nd loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products like breads & biscuits

loans.name: Van's Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan consists of eight members. They are located in Srae Kouk village in Kandal province. The members selected Mrs. Van T., who is 52 years old, as the village bank president. They will each use their portion of the loan for their own purpose. 
 
Mrs. Van T. is a farmer who owns a plot of land that she uses to cultivate rice for a living. Now her rice field is nearly ready for harvesting, but she doesn’t have enough money to support it. She decided to ask for a loan to hire farm laborers for harvesting her rice. Aside from farming, she also earns her living as a vice village chief.

Mrs. Van T. is widow with a child who owns a small stationery shop in their village.

loans.use: To hire farm laborers to harvest her rice.

loans.name: Ruos

texts.en:
Ruos R., 39, lives in Reussey Keo District about 10 km from Phnom Penh. She has seven children. One is married and the others are students who also work at various jobs.

She earns a living as a garment worker in the factory.  She started to work in this sector nearly one year ago, and has a proper salary each month to support her family’s daily expenses. Besides working there, she is a local farmer. She has a life partner in her husband who also works as a farmer. 
 
Ruos R. lacks farming supplies, so she is asking for a loan to buy fertilizer and seeds for growing.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and seeds for growing.

loans.name: Aurelia

texts.en:
Aurelia is from the village of Caputol, Aloran Misamis Occidental. She is 59 years old, married and has five adult-aged children. To make a living, Aurelia runs a business venture in the retail sector. While not the only means for generating revenue, her main source of income comes from operating a retail store in the local community.

Aurelia has been engaged in her business for 15 years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month for these activities. Aurelia joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 14900 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell.

Aurelia is requesting a new loan of 14900 PHP with which she will purchase additional inventory and use for working capital. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Aurelia from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About PMPC
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. 

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Additional capital of her Business

loans.name: Heang's Group

texts.en:
This village loan consists of fifteen members; they are located in Srae Kouk village in Kandal province. This village loan selected, Mrs. Heang M., a 41 year old married woman, as the village bank president. While each member of this village will use their portions of the loan to support their different purpose. 

Mrs. Heang M. is a farmer who rent 1-hectare of land that she uses to cultivate rice. Beside of farmer, she also earns her living by selling tobacco in the local market. Since the tobacco business is going well she wants to expand it. So she decided to ask for a loan to buy more tobacco to resell. Her husband, Mr. Lim vuth, 45 years old, works as construction worker where he can receive a small salary to support his family. 

This couple has two children: One is a car driver and another is a student in the local school.

loans.use: To buy more tobacco to resell.

loans.name: Sen

texts.en: Mrs. Sen T. is a 46 year old married woman who presently lives in Phnom Penh City of Cambodia. She works hard as a fresh fish seller in the busy market and typically earns around $3 per day.  her husband is also earns an income as a building foreman. This couple is married without any children. Mrs. Sen T. is a clever woman and has a good experience managing her fish selling business. As a result of the increasing needs of her clients, Mrs. Sen T. is seeking a loan to purchase more fish to sell.

loans.use: To purchase more fish to sell.

loans.name: Kim

texts.en: Kim S. is a 58-year-old widowed mother in Phnom Penh City. She has a son who currently lives with her in the family home. Her son is employed as a worker in a private factory and is also a bicycle repairman. Kim S. has been working as a primary school teacher for more than ten years in her community. She also provides a vehicle parking service in the school, which fetches her up to $7 a day. Kim S. said that her old motorbike has broken down and she spends much time repairing the vehicle. To reduce repair cost, she would like to request s loan from Kiva to purchase a new motorcycle to replace the broken one.

loans.use: To purchase a new motorcycle to replace a broken one.

loans.name: Res

texts.en:
Res S. is a long-time businesswoman and a low-income person. She has been operating a beauty business since 2005. Res S. owns a kiosk in front of garment factory in Phnom Penh City where she sells a variety of products from her shop. She sells items such as perfumes, beauty products, and some fake jewelry to people who are working in the factory and others. She earns an average income of  $3 per day. 

Res S. is married to 47-year-old, Meas Sambath, who is a motor taxi driver (Tuk Tuk). The coupleare blessed with four children, two of whom are single and the other two are married. In order to earn extra profit and to make the business more successful, Res S. will be using the loan she requested to buy a large supply of  inventory items.

loans.use: To buy a large supply of inventory items.

loans.name: George

texts.en: George is 39 years old and married with two children who are in school. He runs "Geowan Stationery" a business in a very competitive part of Nairobi where he supplies stationery, books and printing paper. He has been running this business for the last fifteen years and employs four people. His main customers are other business people selling stationery. He is requesting for a loan of 80,000 Kes to buy books and printing paper for sale. He describes himself as very hardworking.

loans.use: To buy books and printing papers for sale

loans.name: Marina Uson Group

texts.en:
Marina U. is from the village of Cebu San Isidro. She is 54 years old. Marina is the group leader of a 7-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Marina U.. 

Marina is married and has 4 adult children. To make a living, Marina owns & operates a general store. The main source of income for the business comes  from selling charcoal, fish sauce, salt and other basic commodities.. Marina has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities. 

In 2009, Marina joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marina has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Marina is requesting a new loan of 13000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be Marina's 4th loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Erdenetsetseg
