texts.en: Erdenetsetseg M. is a single mother who lives with her three children in Hovd province of Mongolia. She lives with her children in a ger, a traditional Mongolian housing tent. Her oldest daughter is a university student and her son attends a local secondary school. Since 2000, she had been operating a variety of grocery products selling business and in 2010, he started to sell a cellphone parts. She also sells coal and firewood to supplement  her earnings during winter months. Since operating her own business, she was able to improve her family's standard of living and her earnings have enabled her to buy her own home. For the future, she plans to buy a plot of land and fence for her family. Erdenetsetseg is requesting a 500,000 MNT loan to purchase more coal and firewood to sell.

loans.use: To purchase more coal and firewood to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy another motorcycle

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To add stock of sugar, rice, unga (flour), and cooking fat among other products

loans.name: Teresia Wanjiru

texts.en:
Teresia has practiced dairy farming in Ndunyu Njeru town for the last six years. She is 58 years old. Her husband passed on and she is taking care of her three children by herself. 

Teresia was introduced to KADET LTD by her friend and this will be her fourth loan. She plans to use this loan to buy a dairy cow. She paid all her previous loans well and on time. In the future, Teresia wants to start farming, which will increase her income.

loans.use: To buy a dairy cow

loans.name: Pierre

texts.fr:
PIERRE T. EST UN COMMERÇANT BASE A DAKAR IL EXERCE CE MÉTIER DEPUIS 7 ANS:SON ACTIVITÉ PRINCIPALE EST LA VENTE DE PRÊT A PORTER ET DE CHAUSSURES POUR HOMMES ET FEMMES. LA VARIÉTÉ DE CES PRODUITS S'EXPLIQUE PAR CES VOYAGES EN GAMBIE ET A SANDAGA AFIN DE POUVOIR FIDÉLISER SA CLIENTÈLE SURTOUT LES FILLES ET CES PRODUITS SONT PAR EXEMPLE DES BODYS DES JEANS DES ROBES ETC.
L'OBJET DE CE PRÊT REPOSE SUR LE FAIT QU'IL VEUT RENFLOUER SON FONDS DE ROULEMENT AFIN DE SATISFAIRE LA FORTE DEMANDE DE CES CLIENTS.
texts.en:
Pierre T. is a merchant based in Dakar. He has been in this business for seven years. His main activity is the sale of ready-to-wear clothing and footwear for both men and women. He can offer a wide selection of products due to his travels to Gambia and Sandaga. This allows him to keep a loyal clientele, especially the girls. He sells bodysuits, jeans, dresses, etc. among other things.

He is seeking this loan to strengthen his working capital and meet the high demand of his customers.

loans.use: To strengthen his working capital

loans.name: Habsamet

texts.en:
Habsamet K. is 50 years old and lives with his wife and three daughters in Bayan-Ulgii province in western Mongolia. He and his family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian housing tent. His older two daughters both attend university and his youngest daughter attends a local high school. Habsamet is a very gentle and open-minded man.

Habsamet operates a taxi service during winter months in his town. He has been engaged in this business since 2008, and has gained much experience within a short period of time. In addition, he works in the Cu-Arna partnership to supplement his earnings. His earnings have enabled him to pay his two children's tuition fees. He says, "although my business earnings are not enough to provide my children's education fees, I work very hard to make it work." He is requesting a 1,500,000 MNT loan to purchase necessary spare parts for his taxi business.

loans.use: To purchase necessary spare parts

loans.name: Eliud

texts.en:
Eliud is 42 years old and in business. He operates a transport business in Kiambu, where he transports goods for people for a fee. His main customers are the residents of the town. He is requesting a loan of 60,000 Kes to repair his vehicle. Eliud is a member of Bidii Umoja SHG and the group has guaranteed his loan. 

Eliud also practices dairy farming for extra income. He is married and a father to three children who are in school. His hopes are to excel in the transport business and have a fleet of lorries.

loans.use: To repair his vehicle

loans.name: Jelly

texts.en:
Hope can still be found for someone who has lost the single most important person in her life. A widow at the age of 58, Jelly F. has learned this truth in a rather painful way. Her beloved husband is gone. Jelly finished only high school and has no children to support her. But, a hope still stands beside her. A reason for living has come along when it seemed that nothing was left to live for. Jelly is living not just for herself, but for the people around her whose health and lives she is enriching with the business that she runs. 

Jelly is a CCT* community partner who gains and applies her entrepreneurial training in managing her fruits and vegetables business. She treats this business a treasured thing in life to which she dedicates her effort and resources. She sells healthy foods to people in her community, spreading the wealth of good health to people whose needs she is striving to meet. With this business, Jelly earns Php 9,000 every month, which she uses to meet her daily needs.

Jelly is requesting a loan of Php 9,000 to help her grow her business. She intends to use the money to purchase more fruits and vegetables to add to her table of goods for sale. She looks forward to doing her best to maximize every resource she has to make her business grow.

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay micro finance loans.

loans.use: To purchase fruits and vegetables for sale

loans.name: Sonun Toktakunova's Group

texts.en:
Sonun T. is a 60-year-old widow. She lives with her son, who is 31 and works in construction, and her grandson, who is 14 and in school. In order to make money, Sonun sews Kyrgyz national clothes and sells dressmaking supplies. She has been running this business for 30 years, and now earns 1,500 KGS. Sonun is also engaged in breeding animals. With her loan she wants to purchase five animals for breeding. In the future she wants to expand her business in order to support her grandson financially.

Where did this loan come from?
This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept: People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and society as well), Profit (to be profitable in order to grow further), and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135.
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team – Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – at www.kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To purchase livestock

loans.name: Halhaman

texts.en: Halhaman M. is 26 years old and lives with his wife and one-year-old child in Bayan-Ulgii province of Mongolia. He and his family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. His wife works for the vocational training center in her town. He owns a taxi service transporting people back and forth from Bayan-Ulgii to Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. He started this business in 2009 and has built a stable operation. He has found success with his new business within a very short period and his earnings have enabled him to buy his own car. His current car is outdated therefore he needs to improve his car with a newer car. Halhaman is a very modest and decent man and says, "My goals are to increase my working capital for my business and have my own capital." He is requesting a 3,600,000 MNT loan in order to buy a new car.

loans.use: To buy a new car

loans.name: Adoracion

texts.en:
Adoracion J., a CCT community partner, does not count her losses, but her blessings. At 48, she has been widowed with children to raise. Adoracion was not able to attend college, but she is determined to give her children, her most treasured possessions, a bright future.  The family lives in Pasay City, Philippines.

Adoracion sells dishwashing liquid and fabric conditioner directly. She also has a sari-sari (variety) store where she sells items such as shampoo and soap to meet the needs of her neighborhood.  Adoracion earns about Php400 daily from these small-scale businesses.

Adoracion is requesting a loan of Php48,000 to continue operating her businesses. She will use this money to buy grocery items to replenish her stock and to purchase other products that she will sell directly to her business connections. Adoracion makes every effort possible to reach the goal of making her business prosper. She plans to venture into franchising in the future. 

One challenge she faces is the number of customers who do not pay their debts on time, affecting her cash flow. But she is determined to solve the problem and emerge victorious, because she is focused on her children:  Meeting their daily needs and ensuring that she can send them to school. She also wants to improve the family's house.

All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Mahabat's Group

texts.en:
Mahabat T. is a young woman of 31.  With her spouse, she is raising two small children:  Their son attends school and their daughter is a toddler.

Mahabat’s husband supports the family financially by reselling cattle in the local market. Two years ago, after receiving a profit from selling 2 goats, he began selling cattle.  Over time, their earnings allowed them to increase the total number of  animals they raise and improved the family's quality of life.  

In order to increase the family's income, Mahabat and her husband are seeking to further develop their farming business. They plan to use the loan to purchase goats or sheep. Further plans include fattening the animals and reselling them at a higher price.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan. 

MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase livestock

loans.name: Huanish

texts.en:
Huanish H. is a 41 year-old single father who lives with his sibling and child in Bayan-Ulgii province of Mongolia. He and his family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent home. Huanish has been making framing materials (walls, ceilings, etc.)  for such homes for the past 2 years and has gained a significant experience as a craftsman. 

Huanish operates his business with help of his sibling and usually produces framing for gers according to his customers' orders. He typically spends 200,000 MNT to make a ger's wooden frame and earns 200,000 MNT in profit.  In the winter months, Huanish operates a firewood-selling business to supplement his earnings. Huanish says, " All I want is to provide a good education for my only son."  He is requesting a 500,000 MNT loan to purchase more materials and supplies for his ger frame-making business.

loans.use: To purchase more materials and supplies

loans.name: Flamingo Group

texts.en:
Mwajuma M. is in her late forties. She is married and has a 7-year-old daughter. Mwajuma has been running a food vending business since 2007. Between 6:00 am and 5:00 pm daily, Mwajuma provides ready-cooked meals to her customers. The business earns Mwajuma a low monthly profit. 

This will be Mwajuma's second loan with Tujijenge Tanzania. Mwajuma used her first loan to increase her capital, allowing her to stock up on goods faster when they ran out. This loan has since been successfully repaid. With her second loan, Mwajuma aims to increase her stock and to continue to build herself a new house. 

Mwajuma will share this loan with her loan group Flamingo, which totals 17 members. The members of the group will hold each other accountable for repaying the loans. 

In the picture, Mwajuma can be seen on the far right wearing red.

loans.use: To increase her stock and continue to build herself a new house.

loans.name: Benkadi   (L’Entente) Group

texts.fr:
Benkadi est un regroupement de femmes  du quartier de Mousabougou de la ville Koutiala qui vivent dans de grandes familles traditionnelles avec leurs maris, enfants et autres parents et ont en moyenne 44 ans, sont mariées et mères d’au moins 6 enfants.
Ce groupe de femmes fait le commerce de pagnes, d’habits de toutes sortes et des friperies. 
Pour augmenter la taille de leurs activités, les membres ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso il y a 3 ans. Elles sont à leur sixième prêt de groupe et tous les prêts précédents  ont été bien remboursés.  
Adama Nantoumé qui est un membre du groupe Benkadi vend des habits de toutes sortes : pagnes Dogon, bazins, friperies…, et elle fait également du tricotage de laine (une activité  dans laquelle elle est  aussi sollicitée).  
Elle compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, des pagnes Dogon à Bandiagara, des bazins et quelques friperies à Bamako. Elle vend ses articles en détail et au comptant au grand marché de Koutiala, à la maison,  à une clientèle diverse et variée. 
Tandis que Les membres du groupe comptent réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 160 000FCFA  chacune au  cours de ce cycle, Adama Nantoumé  compte réaliser 190 000FCFA.  
En plus du remboursement des prêts, elles utilisent une partie du revenu  pour faire face aux dépenses courantes de la famille.
texts.en:
Benkadi is a grouping of women from the Mousabougou district of the town of Koutiala; they live in large traditional families with their husbands, children and other relatives, they average 44 years of age and are married with at least six children each.

This group of women sell "pagnes" (a West African term for highly colourful pieces of fabric) as well as all sorts of clothing and second hand clothes. In order to expand their businesses, the members of the group decided to join Soro Yiriwaso's loan program three years ago. They are on their sixth group loan and all the previous loans were repaid in full. 

Adama Nantoumé, who is a member of the Benkadi group, sells all sorts of clothing: Dogon "pagnes", damask fabric, second-hand clothing ..., and she also does wool knitting (an activity for which she is equally in demand). She is planning to use her loan to buy Dogon "pagnes" in Bandiagara, as well as damask fabric and some second-hand clothes in Bamako. She sells her goods on a retail basis for cash at the large market in Koutiala and at home to a diverse customer base. 

While the members of the group are expecting to make a monthly profit of 160,000FCFA each during this cycle, Mrs. Nantoumé is planning to make 190,000FCFA. As well as repaying their loans, the women use part of their income to cover their families' day-to-day expenses.

loans.use: Purchase of clothes

loans.name: Patrick

texts.en: Patrick is 38 years-old and married.  He is a father of four children who are in school. He operates a mali mali (home products sales) business focused on electronics in a Nairobi neighborhood.  He is requesting a loan of 60,000 KES  to add to his stock of radios, loudspeakers, wall clocks, sockets, chargers, switches, water heaters, extensions, bulbs and bulb holders. He hopes to expand his business into an electronics wholesale shop in the future.

loans.use: To add stock of radios, loudspeakers, bulbs and other electronics items.

loans.name: Som

texts.en:
Som P. cultivates a rice crop to earn a living.  Her husband (pictured, because Som P. was not available for the photograph) works as a motor taxi driver in and around Phnom Penh City.

Som P. was born in 1967.  She and her husband are blessed with two children, who are both single and in school. Som P. cultivates a rice crop to earn a living.

Unfortunately, Som P.'s husband's motorbike often breaks down during use. Som P. has decided to seek a loan of $300 from Kiva, which she will use to replace the broken motorcycle.

loans.use: To replace a broken motorcycle.

loans.name: Gulmira's Group

texts.en:
Gulmira K. is divorced, with two sons and a daughter. Her eldest son lives in the capital, and her daughter is married and lives with her husband’s family. Gulmira's youngest son is of preschool age and he lives with her.

Five years ago, after giving birth to her youngest son, Gulmira decided to start her own business making national wares. Now she also earns money by working as a cook in the local café. Out of these total earnings she has managed to organize her daughter's wedding and to prepare a dowry for her. 

Gulmira recently became a grandmother, and she wants to present her newborn grandchild with some gifts: a play-pen and jewelry, as well as organizing a  traditional celebration that is typical of national customs. She is seeking a loan to provide this celebration and gifts.  Her future plans include bringing up her son and buying a home. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan. 

MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To celebrate her grandson's birth

loans.name: Criselda

texts.en:
Just like any loving mother would, Criselda C., 50, gives all her best to make sure her family stays together happily. Criselda only finished high school, but despite that, she strives to excel in everything she puts her hands into. Criselda is married to Roman, who presently has no work. For now, Criselda takes the responsibility of earning money to meet the needs of their children. Together, they presently live in Pasay City, Philippines.

Criselda has managed a sari-sari (variety) store for 10 years now. Alongside her variety store is a small food stall where she basically sells rice and viands (tasty dishes) for her neighborhood. The fact that her store stands near a cemetery in Pasay City speaks of her determination to keep her small business running. Training and Bible studies in CCT* enable Criselda to stand firm on what she knows is right and profitable in business not just for herself but also for others around her. Family members assist Criselda in managing the sari-sari store and food stall. Every month, they earn an average of 7,000 Philippines pesos (Php).

To further help her grow her business, Criselda applied for a Php13,000 loan. She intends to use this money to add more items to her store and make sure her customers, who are mostly visitors to the cemetery, will find what they need in her store. Definitely, Criselda desires to make her business grow and see to it that it would be profitable for her and her family's benefit.

The times when the store has low sales challenge Criselda, as well as debts from her customers that have yet to be paid. She is also worried about her children, who get naughty and need some discipline. Nevertheless, she is determined to overcome these trials and emerge better than she was before, and higher from where she was before. Because, more than a driven entrepreneur, she is a persistent mother who dreams of seeing her children grow as good, responsible citizens. Above all, she prays for a family that stays happily together no matter what.

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: As a means to increase store sales

loans.name: Djiguiya (Hope) Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Djiguiya est constitué de quatre femmes du quartier Mousabougou de la ville de Koutiala qui se connaissent bien. Elles  vivent ensemble dans le même quartier, dans de grandes familles traditionnelles avec leurs maris, enfants et coépouses. Elles ont en moyenne 42 ans, sont mariées et mères d’au moins  6 enfants.
Les membres du groupe Djiguiya font l’achat vente de légumes, d’habillements et de condiments alimentaires.
Pour augmenter la taille de leurs activités, les membres du groupe ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso il y’a trois ans. 
Bintou C. qui est un des membres du groupe Djiguiya vend  exclusivement des bananes. 
Elle compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter au fur et à mesure des bananes. Elle se procure de ces marchandises  dans les marchés environnant Koutiala notamment Soukoumba et Molobala. Elle vend ces bananes en gros aux jeunes filles qui ensuite partent vendre en détail  dans la ville de Koutiala, l’autre partie est vendue au marché de Yangasso en gros, au comptant et en détail.  
Tandis que Les autres membres du groupe  comptent réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 105 000FCFA chacune au  cours de ce cycle, Bintou C.,  compte réaliser 120 000 FCFA.  
En plus du remboursement des prêts, elles utilisent une partie du revenu  pour faire face aux dépenses courantes de la famille. 
Elles souhaitent renforcer leur partenariat avec Soro Yiriwaso afin de  diversifier  leurs activités.
texts.en:
Djiguiya is a group composed of four women from the Mousabougou district in the city of Koutiala who know one another well.  They live together in the same district and in large traditional families with their husbands, children, and co-spouses.  Averaging 42 years of age, the women are married and the mothers of at least six children.  The group members buy and sell vegetables, clothing, and condiments. To increase the size of their businesses, they decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso loan program three years ago.  

Bintou C., a member of the group, sells bananas exclusively. She plans on using her loan to buy bananas when needed.  She acquires her merchandise at markets surrounding Koutiala, especially Soukoumba and Molobala.  She sells these bananas wholesale to girls who then go sell them retail in the city of Koutiala.  The other portion is sold at the Yangasso market retail and wholesale for cash. 

While the other group members each plan on making an average profits of 105,000 francs CFA over the course of the cycle, Bintou C. plans on making 120,000 francs.  

In addition to repaying the loan, the group members are using a portion of the revenues to cope with everyday family expenses.  They would like to bolster their partnership with Soro Yiriwaso in order to diversify their businesses.

loans.use: Buying bananas

loans.name: Jaih

texts.en: Jaih H. is 39 years old and lives with his wife and two children in the Bayan-Ulgii province of western Mongolia. He and his family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Jaih operates a meat-trading business out of his own stall at the local market in his town. He began his business in 1999 with working capital of 200,000 Mongolin tugriks (MNT). After several years of operation, his working capital has grown to a level of 800,000 MNT today and he has managed to establish himself in the business community. Jaih says, "I want to expand my business and buy my own car in the future." He is requesting a 1,000,000 MNT loan in order to increase his working capital due to an increase in the price of livestock.

loans.use: To increase his working capital

loans.name: Daniel

texts.en:
Daniel is 33 years old. He owns and runs the Ebenezer Shop in Kiambu. He has been running this business for four years and he employs two people. 

Daniel is married and a father of two children who are in school. 

He is requesting a loan of 60,000 Kenyan shillings to start another retail shop. He also operates a timber yard to earn extra income. He hopes to begin a microfinance institution in the future.

loans.use: To start another retail shop

loans.name: Ma Theresa

texts.en:
Nobody wants an unfinished task. Knowing that a winner never quits, Ma Theresa A., moves on from her past with conviction that she will finish whatever she has started, and finish it well. At 46, Theresa is married to Emilio, an employee, and together they raise a child who is now in high school. Theresa did not finish college, but she makes sure that unfinished tasks will never happen again in her life, or the life of her child.

Theresa presently runs a sari-sari (variety) store out of her residence. Being in the business for ten years now, Theresa has been doing well in her business and is earning around 9,000 PHP per month. Bible studies and trainings at CCT* also give her enough encouragement to keep growing and dreaming for greater things in her business and family.

Part of any business is staying profitable, healthy and growing. So to help her grow her business, Theresa has requested a loan for 20,000 PHP. She will use this money to add more items to her store and attract more customers. She also wants to renovate her store and plans to use part of the loan money to start the renovation. She believes that more products on her shelves and a better-looking store would help increase her monthly income.

At present, Theresa admits finding it hard to be in competition with many other sari-sari stores in her area. Also, there are customers who are hard to follow up with in terms of their debts. Theresa also thinks of her child’s high school expenses. However, despite these financial problems, Theresa is certain that she will end up finishing the race of life and emerging the winner. She dreams of seeing her business expand and eventually have branches in many locations. She also desires to help her mother out and of course, to see her child finish college with flying colors.

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay micro finance loans.

loans.use: Store renovation

loans.name: Isaac Karanja

texts.en:
Isaac has practiced farming in Ndunyu Njeru town for the last 10 years. He is 37 years old, married to Mary Nyawira Karaya, and they have four children.

He got to know about KADET through various marketing activities carried out by KADET staff in Ndunyu Njeru town. He repaid his first loan well and in good time. He plans to use the current loan amount to purchase a cow.

In the future, Isaac hopes to increase farm production by practicing large-scale farming, hence improving his living standards.

loans.use: To buy a cow

loans.name: Nadutari Enle

texts.en:
Nadutari Enole N. is 29 years old. She is married to Rereu Ole Pere and a mother of seven school-aged children between 4 and 15 years old.

Nadutari is a farmer and has farmed her own piece of land for the last 13 years.

She learned about KADET LTD from other women registered with KADET in her area of residence. This will be Nadutari's second loan. She plans to spend the 40,000 KES to prepare land for planting maize. Maize has been doing well in her area due to good climatic conditions.

She hopes to use the profit from the proceeds of this loan to expand her farming activity from small-scale to commercial farming. Nadutari's dream is to farm on a large scale and attain financial independence. She is a hard working woman who is determined to achieve her goals.

loans.use: To prepare land for planting maize

loans.name: Bahatbek

texts.en: Bahatbek H. is 50 years old and lives with his wife and four children in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic home tent, in the Bayan-Ulgii province of western Mongolia. All of his four children attend a local school and his wife is currently unemployed and helps him with the business, working as a salesperson when he goes to procure his products. Bahatbek operates a retail clothing business from his own small pavilion at the local market. He began his business in 2003, selling a variety of clothes in the outdoor stall at the local market. After years of successful operation, he was able to build a small pavilion, where he sells his products, in 2008. Over the years, the business profits have enabled him to provide for his entire family. Bahatbek is a very modest gentleman and hopes to increase his working capital and earn a lot of profits. He is requesting a 1,000,000 Mongolian tugriks loan to increase his working capital for his clothing business.

loans.use: To increase his working capital and earn a lot of profits

loans.name: Jennifer

texts.en: Consistency is the key for CCT* community partner Jennifer L., who wants to keep her business in shape. Jennifer, 34, reached college and is married to Josefino, who works as a messenger. Josefino and Jennifer have three children and together they reside in Pasay City, south of Manila. Jennifer has started a frozen food business, in which she sells products like longganisa (sausage) and tocino (cured meat) to neighbors and household people in their community. Jennifer also cooks viands (tasty dishes) so that neighbors who are in the rush and can not find time to cook their own meals can have a good meal from Jennifer's store and get going with their work. Jennifer earns a monthly income of 7,900 Philippines pesos (Php). To help her continue operation of her business, Jennifer is requesting a Php 20,000 loan. She will use the money to buy more stocks of frozen food and enough ingredients for a daily variety of delicious viands for her customers to choose from. Jennifer desires to be able to put up a restaurant someday, and as stated, her consistency to provide excellent products is the key. She badly needs to maintain a consistently profitable business in order to meet the daily needs of her children. As many small-scale entrepreneurs admit, Jennifer also finds it challenging to deal with customers with long lists of debts. But no challenge, no matter how difficult, can stop her from consistently working with all her strength in order to be able to send her children to school up until college. She envisions have her own house and living in it with a happy, successful family. *All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: Purchase of frozen food and other items for sale

loans.name: Chynargul's Group

texts.en: Chynargul E. is a citizen of a lakeside town. She is married and, together with her husband, is raising two daughters and twin sons. All of the children are school pupils. Chynargul and her spouse improve their living standard by working in the same establishment. The head of the family is a chief of the shooting-ground (his salary comes to 11,700 soms per month). Earlier, Chynargul in the same place had a job as the cook, and a month ago, she opened her own dining room in the building. Out of the earnings, she has managed to obtain household appliances. In order to purchase foodstuff and vary the canteen menu, the woman hopes to get a loan. In the future, she plans to open a café, to obtain a car and give a good upbringing to her children. Where Did This Loan Come From? This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple "P" bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase foodstuffs

loans.name: Betty

texts.en:
Betty N. lives in the Kisaasi neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda. She is married and has 6 children, all of whom are in school. She also takes care of additional family members (two cousins). Betty lives in a home that she owns. She has access to electricity and to piped water. Her major monthly expenses include food and school fees.   

Betty has a retail shop business. She has been in this business for 10 years, and she works 7 days out of every week. Betty sells her products in a shop by retail means. She also generates additional income through rental rooms. The main business challenge(s)for Betty includes thieves and transportation. Her goals and aspirations for her business are to own a wholesale shop and also to build more rental rooms.

Betty has requested a loan of 2000000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO. She will use the loan to buy more boxes of soap, cartons of salt, bags of sugar and maize flour and jerrycans of cooking oil.

loans.use: To buy more boxes of soap, bags of sugar, cartons of salt, bags of maize flour and jerrycans of cooking oil

loans.name: Janarbek

texts.en: Janarbek M. lives with his wife and daughter in the Bayan-Ulgii province of Mongolia. He and his family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. His wife works as an English teacher for the local school and Janarbek operates a PLAY STATION 2 PC game center in his town. He began his business in 2009 and has built a stable operation. His game center is equipped with the latest equipment and tools, which attracts many customers. His PC game center is the only one to exist in the local community and therefore his income and demand are usually high. In the future he plans to open another branch of his PC game center. Janarbek is an open-minded man with initiative, and he says, "All I want is to establish the best service center in my town in the future." He is requesting a 3,000,000 MNT loan to buy more computers and televisions for his PC game center.

loans.use: To buy more computers and televisions

loans.name: Marina's Group

texts.en:
Marina O. is a wife and mother of three children. Her husband makes his livelihood working as an odd-job-man and his salary comes to 6000 soms per month. Their elder children are school pupils while the youngest is preschool age.

Apart from working as a general odd-job-man, the head of the family supports the family financially by cattle breeding. This business has been bringing in a return for 10 years. The main aim of getting a loan is to purchase cattle to increase stock.

In the future, Marina’s family wishes to improve their living standard. They are parents aimed at giving a proper upbringing and education to their children.
 


--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase cattle

loans.name: Karei

texts.en:
Karei S. Isaac is 26 years old. He is married to Rita and is a father of two children. He has been farming his own piece of land for the last five years.

Karei learned about KADET from a member of a group that is registered with KADET. This will be his fifth loan with KADET, and he is planning to use it to prepare his land for the next maize-planting season. Maize has proved to do well in his area due to good climate conditions. With the profits he hopes to make, he plans to re-invest in the farm and plant more acres of maize.

Karei's hope and dream is to become a large-scale farmer in maize and to buy a bigger piece of land.

loans.use: To prepare his land for the next maize-planting season.

loans.name: Muratbek

texts.en:
Muratbek S. is 38 years old and lives with his wife and four children in the Bayan-Ulgii province of Mongolia. He and his family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. His three oldest children attend a local school, and his youngest son is in kindergarten. His wife works as a librarian, and Muratbek operates a coal-delivery business using his own truck. 

Muratbek began his transportation business in 2000 and has gained much experience as a driver. After many years of owing his business, he has established a wide customer base. Muratbek is a hardworking and decent man and says, " All I want is to improve my truck, which is very outdated and requires a lot of repairs." He is requesting a loan of 1,100,000 Mongolian tugriks (MNT) to increase his working capital for his coal-delivery business.

loans.use: To repair his truck

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth N. lives in the Kisaasi neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda. She is married and has 3 children, all of whom are in school. She has a retail business selling charcoal. She has been in this business for 5 years, and she works 7 days a week. She sells her products from home.

Elizabeth has requested a loan of 1,000,000 Ugandan shillings (UGX) from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bags of charcoal. She generates additional income by selling piped water.  Her main business challenges include thieves and transportation.

Her goals and aspirations are to start selling charcoal on wholesale only and to build more rental rooms. Elizabeth lives in a home that she owns; she has access to electricity and piped water. Her major monthly expenses include food and school fees.

loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal

loans.name: Anarkul's Group

texts.en: Anarkul M. is coping with the task of being a mother and a businesslike woman. Unfortunately, as fate has willed, she lost her husband. But by her own strength, she has managed to give a proper upbringing to three children: two sons and a daughter. The youngest child is a 7th-grade pupil. All the adult family members increase their common budget by working in different spheres: the eldest son raises money by building (his salary comes to 4,000 soms per month), while the daughter works for a private sewing workshop. Besides this, the most important source of income comes from selling national drinks (10 to 15 liters daily). This business has been run for 10 years and during this time, the family has managed to improve their living standard. In order to increase her level of income, Anarkul wants to obtain cattle for fattening and raising. For this purpose, she hopes to get a loan. For the future, this woman has the following plans: to arrange her son’s marriage and to prepare a dowry for her daughter. Where Did This Loan Come From? This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple "P" bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase cattle

loans.name: Phoebe

texts.en:
Phoebe is a 26-year-old business lady. She operates a boutique, where she sells clothes and handbags. Her customers are mainly middle-income earners. 

She is married and a mother of one child who goes to school. She is requesting a loan of 50,000 Kenyan shillings to buy handbags, dresses, trousers, sweaters, suits, baby clothes and shirts, among other clothing for sale. She hopes to acquire several plots of land and develop them for rental purposes in the future.

loans.use: To buy handbags, dresses, trousers, sweaters, suits, baby clothes and shirts, among other clothing

loans.name: Tiwae Ole

texts.en:
Tiwae Ole N. is 56 years old. He is married to Kinyeketa N. and he is a father of three children. 

Tiwae is a farmer and he has been doing farming on his own piece of land for the last four years.
  
He learned about KADET from a member of a group within his locality that is registered with KADET. This will be his first loan and he is planning to prepare 15 acres for wheat planting in the next planting season. Wheat normally does well in his area due to good climatic conditions. With the profits he hopes to make from the proceeds of this loan, he plans to reinvest in the farm and plant more acres of wheat.

His hope and dream is to become a large-scale farmer and be able to buy his own farm machinery.

loans.use: To prepare 15 acres of land for wheat planting in the next season

loans.name: Nancy Njeri

texts.en:
Nancy Njeri G. is a widow, aged 57, and a mother of four children. She has been running a spice business in Kongowea, Mombasa, Kenya for the last 14 years with good profits.

This will be Nancy's second loan from KADET. She plans to use the loan to purchase more spices for resale and to reinvest the anticipated profits to expand her business.

Her dream is to grow her business and become a wholesaler.

loans.use: To purchase more spices

loans.name: Harrison Sirikia

texts.en:
Harrison, 28 years old, has been farming in Naivasha since 2003.  He rotates between planting cabbage and wheat.

Harrison was introduced to KADET by a friend, and this will be his second loan.  He paid his previous loan of 50,000 Kenyan shillings (KES) in good time.  He plans to plant wheat and buy fertilizer with the new loan.

In the future, Harrison hopes to buy his own farming equipment and save on having to rent equipment every time he wants to plant or harvest.

loans.use: To plant wheat and buy fertilizer

loans.name: Huanish

texts.en:
Huanish A. is 43 years old and lives with his wife and three children in the Bayan-Ulgii province of Mongolia. He and his family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. All of his three children attend the local secondary school while his wife works as a salesperson in the local grocery shop. 

Huanish operates an animal raw-material trading business in his local market. He purchases raw materials from the countryside and sells them at his local market as a retailer. He began the business in 2003 and has built a stable operation. In addition, he also works as a driver in a company to supplement his earnings. 

Today, his working capital exceeds 500,000 Mongolian tugriks (MNT). He plans to buy his own car in the future. He is requesting a 500,000 MNT loan to increase his working capital for his raw-material trading business.

loans.use: To purchase animal rawhides

loans.name: Naskul's Group

texts.en:
Naskul A. is married to a farmer. She is 39 years old. She takes care of five children; the eldest daughter is a capital university student, the rest of the children except the youngest son, who is of preschool age, are school pupils. 

This big family needs large funds. That’s why they want to increase their profits out of harvesting. Naskul wants to get a loan in order to purchase potato seeds for spring sowing.  Future plans involve increasing cattle stock, purchasing a larger home and paying for their children's education. The family is interested in achieving the best possible results.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 

MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase potato seeds

loans.name: Bertha Ngai

texts.en:
Bertha Ngai N., 45, operates a retail shop and sells household items from Githurai. The area is highly populated so Bertha has many customers. She is married to Charles Kinyua and together they have seven children. The oldest is 25 years old and the last born is 4 years old. Her husband helps support their family.  Bertha was introduced to KADET by existing KADET clients.

Bertha’s retail shop has been in operation for 20 years and her monthly income is 68,800 KES. This loan of 40,000 KES will be her second loan from KADET. The previous loan of 20,000 KES was serviced successfully.

With the loan she intends to add more stock of household goods like sufurias, cups, basins, buckets and jugs which are always in high demand. With the extra profits, Bertha will expand her business and start a supply of household goods to smaller businesses.

Bertha hopes to open a wholesale operation which will supply other towns and employ many sales people.

loans.use: To add more stock of household goods

loans.name: Bermet's Group

texts.en:
Bermet J. is simultaneously a wife, mother and mother-in-law. She is 52 years old, and her only son is already married and together with his young wife lives with his parents.

The family makes their living in different ways; the head of the family is a private driver (he has his own car), the son earns money by working at a mill, his wife is an employee of the local school. Concurrently, all family members are engaged in trading and farming. Trading includes barley and wheat reselling, and their farming involves cattle breeding. 

In order to increase the common family budget, Bermet wants to develop the business involving cattle breeding. To accomplish this, she plans to purchase animals for further fattening and resale. For this goal to come true, the family hopes to obtain a loan. In the future they want to purchase a new home.

	--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 

MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). 

MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase cattle

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en:
Sarah C. is a 42-year-old business lady married to Joseph C., a public transport driver.  They both work to support the family. She has seven children between the ages of 17 and 2 years old. 

Sarah is a resident of Kipsirichet centre, 3 km from Londiani Town, Kericho district served by the Kadet Koibatek office. She runs a general product kiosk at Kipsirichet centre and also sells clothes in small quantities.

This will be Sarah's first loan from KADET, totaling 15,000 KES. She intends to use 8,000 KES of the loan to restock her shop and use the remaining amount of 7,000 KES to buy young chicks (broilers and layers).

She anticipates using her profits to purchase more chicks to boost her income in the future. Her hopes are for her poultry business to grow, so that she will be supplying broilers and eggs to Londiani, Kericho, and other nearby towns.

loans.use: To purchase goods for the store and to buy poultry

loans.name: Kipelian Ole

texts.en:
Kipelian Ole N. is 37 years old. He is married to Lantano Kirtela and he is the father of two school children, ages five and eight years. 

Kipelian is a farmer and he does the farming on his own piece of land which he has been doing for the last five years.

He learned about KADET from a colleague who is already a KADET registered client. This will be his second loan. He is planning to spend 20,000 KES to hire farm machinery for harvesting his wheat. With the profits he hopes to make from the proceeds of this loan, he plans to hire more land for farming to increase his wheat output.

His future dream is that he will be able to buy a bigger piece of land whereby he can be planting more wheat in a larger scale.

Despite his age, Kipelian believes he is hard working and having the right resources at his disposal he can achieve a lot.

loans.use: To hire farm machinery for harvesting his wheat.

loans.name: Kymbat's Group

texts.en:
Kymbat M. is a woman of middle age. She is married to a person who worked as a cattleman, but now he is a pensioner. The couple gave birth to and raised seven children. Today all of them, except the youngest daughter who is a student, are married and live separately from their parents.  

The rural way of life in most cases involves cattle breeding. Kymbat‘s family has been doing that for 20 years. This uncomplicated business brings stable income. Out of the profits, the family has managed to pay for their children’s study at university.

In order to increase the family funds, Kymbat wants to purchase more cattle to fatten and resell.  For this purpose she hopes to obtain a loan.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase cattle to fatten and resell

loans.name: Vaisiddin

texts.en:
B. Vaisiddin is married. His family lives in Kumsangir, Southern Tajikistan. Vaisiddin sells household items in his shop. Small ventures like Nuriddin’s has become the only source of income for families in remote parts of Tajikistan. 

Vaisiddin has been in the trade for 5 years. His business is characterized by stability and positive performance. The inventory he sells is always in demand as people need dishwasher, laundry soap, shampoos, perfumes, and other household items. 

Vaisiddin wants to see his business growing in the future, which is why he is requesting a loan of $3000 USD to increase his turnover capital. He is hoping to boost further development of his business with this additional assistance. 

 
More about Tajikistan and IMON International:

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To increase inventory range

loans.name: Mendgul

texts.en:
Mendgul D. is 36 years old and lives with her husband and three sons in the Bayan-Ulgii province of Western Mongolia. She and her family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Her two sons both attend a local secondary school and her husband works as an assistant driver of a bus. 

Mendgul operates a handicraft-making business out of her home, where she produces a variety of souvenir products according to her customer's specification and order. She started her business in 2005 and has since built a stable operation. In addition, she also started to work at a tailoring company in 2006 to supplement her earnings. 

Mendgul says, “I wish to establish my own tailoring factory in the future.” She is requesting a 600,000 MNT loan in order to buy more materials and supplies for her handicraft-making business.

loans.use: To buy materials and supplies

loans.name: John Nganga

texts.en:
John Nganga M. is a 42-year-old businessman. He is married to Elizabeth, and they are blessed with two children. He is in the transport business and has owned a retail shop for the last six years. This will be his fifth loan from KADET.  

With his loan, he plans to purchase beans, rice, maize, and sugar. He will direct the anticipated profits into the expansion of his business.  John’s dream is to expand his transport business through the addition of more motorbikes.

loans.use: To purchase beans, rice, maize, and sugar

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To add stocks of milk for sale

loans.name: Nulu

texts.en:
Nulu K. lives in the Bwaise neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda.  She is married and has 6 children, 3 of whom are in school.  Nulu has a pharmacy business.  She has been in this business for over 10 years, and she works 7 days out of every week.  

Nulu sells her products in a shop by means of retail.     Nulu has requested a loan of 900000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more boxes of syrups and drugs.     She also generates additional income through selling piped water and dry cleaning.

The main business challenges for Nulu include thieves and the rainy season.  Her goal for her business is to own a fully stocked pharmacy.  

Nulu lives in a home that she owns.  She has access to electricity and piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include food, school fee, and rent for her business premises.

loans.use: To buy more syrups and drugs

loans.name: Anorbegim

texts.en:
Anorbegim is married with two children. She runs a pharmaceutical business. Anorbegim owns one small pharmaceutical kiosk and sells medications to retail clients. She launched this business 14 years ago. Olga is seeking a loan of 5000 Somoni to purchase assorted pharmaceuticals for the cold season when viruses, cold, and flu lead to increased spending on medications. 

Anorbegim’s business is the main source of income for the family and her husband is also actively involved in the business.  Anorbegim hopes to continue to develop her business by opening several more pharmaceutical kiosks.


More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase medications for pharmacy sale

loans.name: Taatai Ole

texts.en:
Taatai Ole K. is 41 years old. He is married to Nayuyanye K. and is a father of six school-going children. He has been farming on his own piece of land for the last ten years.

This will be his second loan.  He learned about KADET from a colleague who was already a KADET client. He is planning to spend KES 40,000 to prepare his land for the next planting season, and spend the remaining KES 10,000 to buy chemicals and fertilizer for his twenty acres of maize. With the profits he hopes to make from the proceeds of this loan, he plans to lease more land for farming to increase his maize output and also further develop his own plot.

In the future, he hopes to be able to buy a bigger piece of land so that he can plant maize on a larger scale. Taatai believes he is hardworking and that with the right resources at his disposal he can achieve a lot.

loans.use: To prepare land for planting season, and buy chemicals & fertilizer

loans.name: Norjmaa

texts.en:
Norjmaa D. is 47 years old and lives with her three children and husband in a Mongolian nomadic dwelling called a ger in the Chigeltei district of Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia. Her husband helps her with her business, her oldest son attends university, and her two daughters attend high school. Her husband is also very good at making wooden products, thus adding profits to their family earnings. 

Norjmaa operates a cooking oil trading business.  The oil is made from animal fat. She buys animal fat in large amounts and makes cooking oils in her storehouse next to her home.  She sells them to the sellers in the Huchit Shonhor market, one of the largest market in the city. 

For the future, she hopes to continue the stable operation of her business and to expand. Norjmaa is requesting a 500,000 MNT loan to purchase a large amount of animal fat when the price for such product is cheap.

loans.use: To purchase animal fats in bulk

loans.name: Christine

texts.en:
Christine, a widowed mother of seven, operates her "Jitegemee Dressmaking" business, where she offers tailoring and dressmaking services. She employs one person and has a combination of institutional and individual customers. She has been operating this business for ten years and is a member of Jitegemee Ufaulu SHG. 

Christine is requesting a loan of Kes 50,000 to pay school fees for her children. She hopes to become a millionaire in the future. When asked about Faulu Kenya, she says, "Faulu has taught me how to keep my records and deal with customers."  When asked about herself, she says, "I am good in business."

loans.use: To pay school fees for her children

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en:
Sarah L. is a 28-year-old business woman and is married to Joshua. She has run a boutique in the town of Mariakani for the last ten years.

This marks her second loan from KADET and her plan is to purchase clothing and women's shoes. With the anticipated profits, she plans to expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase garments and women's shoes

loans.name: Parioti Ene

texts.en:
Parioti Ene has been raising livestock in Naivasha town for the last three years. She is 46 years old and a widow who takes care of her two children.

She was introduced to KADET by her friend. This will be her first loan. She plans to use the loan amount to buy 15 goats and 10 sheep, which she will raise and sell later at a profit.

In the future, Parioti hopes to increase her income and be able to send all of her children to school.

loans.use: To buy 15 goats and 10 sheep

loans.name: Kodirjon

texts.en:
G. Kodirjon is 30 years old. He is an optimistic and hardworking husband. He works his land with love and dedication every day, so that it produces excellent crops. In fact, he draws strength and vitality from his work, which help to make his products the best in the city. Kodirjon has been working in agriculture for more than five years. His loving wife is also involved in the business. Though growing vegetables is a very difficult and time-consuming job, he hopes to gather a rich harvest. He is planning to fix the house and save enough money for the well-being of his family. He is requesting a loan of 8000 TJS and appeals to your generous hearts for a swift contribution.     

 
More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.
